libemf module¶

Routines for constant fitting from potentiometric data.

Module libemf contains the routines needed for fitting equilibrium constants from potentiometric data. The main function to invoke here is emffit() which handles most of the work. This is the only public function for this module.

Functions included in this module

libemf.build_reduced_emf(emf, emf0, nernst)¶

Build reduced EMF.

Parameters

  • emf (numpy.ndarray) –

  • emf0 (float) –

  • nernst (float) –

libemf.dcdt(concentration, stoichiometry, starting_volume, titre)¶

Calculate ∂c/∂T.

T is the analytical concentration which is defined as \(T_i = \frac{a_i v_0 + b_i v}{v_0 + v}\) where \(a_i\) is the initial ammount for the component i and \(b_i\) is the buret concentration for the component i.

Parameters

  • concentration (numpy.ndarray) – The full free concentration array (N, E+S).

  • stoichiometry (numpy.ndarray) – The stoichiometry array.

  • starting_volume (numpy.ndarray or float) – The starting volume

  • titre (numpy.ndarray) – The titre volume

Returns

where the first element is an (N, S, S) array where each element

(i,j,k) is ∂c[i,j]/∂a[k]. The second element of the tuple is also an (N,S,S) array each element (i,j,k) are ∂c[i,j]/∂b[k].

Return type

tuple

libemf.emf_jac1(stoichiometry, free_conc, fh, var=())¶

Calculate jacobian.

Return jacobian for potentiometric titrations when T and E0 are constant, based on logarithmic betas and dimmensionless potentials.

Notes: It is done this way because requires less input for the function

and the result can be conveniently transformed by the calling function with simple operations. \(E* = E / (fRT/nF)\)

\[\frac{\partial E^*}{\partial \log \beta} = \frac1{C_h} \frac{\partial C_h}{\partial \log \beta} = \frac{\partial\log C_h}{\partial \log \beta}\]

where \(\frac{\partial C_h}{\partial \log \beta}\) has to be derived first from the set of linear equations

\[\sum_{k=1}^S \left( \delta_{ki} + \sum_{j=1}^E { p_{ji} p_{jk} \frac{c_{j+S}}{c_k} } \right) \frac{\partial c_k}{\partial \log\beta_b} = -p_{bi}c_{b+S}\]
Parameters

  • stoichiometry (numpy.ndarray) – stoichiometric coefficients

  • free_conc (numpy.ndarray of floats) – free concentrations

  • fh (callable) – Function that applied to an array returns from it the electroactive species only.

Returns

2D-array of floats containing the jacobian

in the form ∂emf/∂logβ.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Raises

RuntimeError – if jacobian couldn’t be computed

libemf.emf_jac2(stoichiometry, free_conc, fh, titration, electrode)¶

  • starting ammounts

  • buret concentrations

  • standard potentials

  • free_conc (numpy.ndarray) – the free concentration array

libemf.emf_res(electroactive_conc, emf, emf0, nernst)¶

Calculate the residuals for potentiometric data.

The residuals are calculated as \(\chi = emf_{meas}-emf_{calc}\). and \(emf_{calc}\) is calculated through Nernst’s equation.

Parameters

  • electroactive_conc (numpy.ndarray) – a 1D array of floats representing the free concentrations of the electroactive species.

  • emf (numpy.ndarray) – a 1D array of floats representing the experimental values for the potential

  • emf0 (float) – The standard potential

  • nernst (float) – The slope for Nernst’s equation

Returns

a 1D array of floats containing the residuals.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

libemf.emffit(beta, beta_flags, stoichiometry, titration_data, electrodes, method=0, **kwargs)¶

Potentiometry data fitting.

Parameters

  • beta (numpy.ndarray) – 1D-array of floats representing the initial guess for the constants in log10units.

  • beta_flags (sequence) – refinement flags for values in ‘beta’.

  • stoichiometry (numpy.ndarray) – The stoichiometry array in the usual format.

  • titration_data (iterable of dict) –

    Information about the titrations. Each member of the list is one titrations. Every element in the list is a dict for which the accepted keys are:

    • V (numpy.ndarray): volume of titre in mL.

    • emf (numpy.ndarray): containing emf measured in mV. It

      must be of the same size than :var:`V`. Each element can be a float or a tuple of floats if more then one electrode is being used.

    • weights (numpy.ndarray): The weights for each

      experimental point. It must be of the same size than :var:`emf`.

    • V0 (float): the initial volume in mL

    • T0 (sequence): total amount of initial components in mmol

    • buret (sequence): concentration in the buret for each component in mmol/mL.

    • Tflags (sequence, optional): The refinement flag for T0

    • buret_flags (sequence, optional): The refinement flag for emf0

    • T (numpy.ndarray): An (N, S)-array with the initial concentrations. If provided, V, V0, T0, buret and Tflags are ignored.

    • error_V (float):

  • electrodes (iterable of dict) –

    • E0 (numpy.ndarray): Value for standard potential for each curve in mV. If more than one electrode is used, tuples are accepted.

    • E0flags (numpy.ndarray, optional): refinement flags for E0 in the same format.

    • hindex (list of ints or tuples of ints): Index or indices for the electrode sensitive species (usually, the proton H +).

    • fRTnF (float or list of Nd-floats): by default 25.67968mV (1 atm, 298K, 1 electron, f=1). If float, assume it is the same value for all sets and internally converted into a list.

    • error_emf (float):

  • method (int) – A number indicating the method to be used to mimize the objective functions. Allowed values are 0 for the algorithm by Levenberg-Marquardt (nonlinear least squares, this is the default one) and 1 for the Nelder-Mead algorithm (the simplex method).

  • logbeta_flag (bool, optional[True]) – False by default. If true B0 is assumed to be the log:sup:10 of the constants to be refined.

  • free_concentration_guess (sequence, optional) – The free concentrations used as initial guess for concentration calculations.

  • debug (bool, optional) – returns a text with debug information

  • verbosity (int, optional) – An 0-2 number indicating the level of verbosity to be printed. 0 for mute, 1 for normal and 2 for pedanting output.

  • htmlout (callable, optional) – A callable function that accepts an html snippet to be output.

Returns

First element is a 1D numpy.ndarray of floats: The values of the refined parameters. The second element is a list of 2D numpy.ndarray of floats which are the final values of the free concentrations.

Return type

tuple

libemf.emfsim(beta, stoichiometry, titration, electrodes, **kwargs)¶

Simulate emf titrations. Return calculated emf.

Parameters

  • beta (numpy.ndarray) – 1D-array of floats representing the stability constants.

  • stoichiometry (numpy.ndarray) – The stoichiometry array in the usual format.

  • titration (iterable of dict) – Information about the titrations. Each member of the list is one titrations. See structure of this dict at emffit().

  • electrodes (iterable of dict) – See structure of this dict at emffit().

Yields

calculated emf.

libemf.fit_final_calcs(jacobian, resids, weights)¶

Perform final calculations common to some routines.

Parameters

  • jacobian (numpy.array) – the jacobian

  • resids (numpy.array) – the residuals

  • weights (numpy.array) – the weights

Returns

  • the error in beta

  • the correlation matrix

  • the covariance matrix

libemf.hselect(array, hindices, slices)¶

Select columns that correspond to the electroactive species.

Given the concentrations array, selects the columns that correspond to the electroactive species.

Parameters

  • array (numpy.ndarray) – The free concentrations array

  • hindices (list) – List of ints or list of lists of ints with the indices of the electroactive species. Example: [[0,1],[1,2],[3,4],[4,5]]. hindices are applied along axis=0

  • slices (list of ints) – Where to divide C. Example: [ 0, 5, 10, 15 ] slices are applied along axis=1

Returns

The part of C which is electroactive

>>> slices = [0, 4, 7]
>>> hindices = [[0,1],[1,2],[3,4]]
>>> C = np.array([[ 0.255,  0.638,  0.898,  0.503,  0.418],
...               [ 0.383,  0.789,  0.731,  0.713,  0.629],
...               [ 0.698,  0.080,  0.597,  0.503,  0.456],
...               [ 0.658,  0.399,  0.332,  0.700,  0.294],
...               [ 0.534,  0.556,  0.762,  0.493,  0.510],
...               [ 0.637,  0.065,  0.638,  0.770,  0.879],
...               [ 0.598,  0.193,  0.912,  0.263,  0.118],
...               [ 0.456,  0.680,  0.049,  0.381,  0.872],
...               [ 0.418,  0.456,  0.430,  0.842,  0.172]])
>>> hselect(C, hindices, slices)
array([[0.255, 0.638], [0.383, 0.789], [0.698, 0.080], [0.658, 0.399],
       [0.556, 0.762], [0.065, 0.638], [0.193, 0.912], [0.381, 0.872],
       [0.842, 0.172]])
